speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a little bit about how you were born, was it a normal delivery or did you have any complications during birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I was delivered at term, it was a pretty routine process, but I'm not really sure about the details, my mom didn't get any prenatal care, so I don't have all the information about what happened during delivery.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me a bit more about your mother's pregnancy, did she have any symptoms or complications during her pregnancy, such as severe morning sickness, excessive weight gain, or any unusual cravings?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, my mom didn't mention anything unusual. She just kind of... stopped going to the doctor after a while, and that's about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Did your mother ever experience any unusual bleeding or discharge during her pregnancy, or was there a significant amount of blood in the amniotic fluid at the time of delivery?

speaker: Patient
text: No, my mom didn't mention anything about unusual bleeding or discharge. She just said she didn't feel well, but she didn't think much of it, and that's why she didn't go back to the doctor.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about your birth weight and length? Was you significantly larger or smaller than your siblings or average newborns?

speaker: Patient
text: I was a pretty small baby, weighing about 3000 grams, which is about 6.6 pounds. I'm actually one of the smallest babies born to my mom, but I'm doing okay so far.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about your mother's age and any previous pregnancies she's had? Was she a young mother or had she had any complications with previous pregnancies?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom is 23 years old, and this is her first pregnancy. She's never been pregnant before, so I'm not really sure about any complications she might have had with previous pregnancies.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to do a physical examination to get a better understanding of your condition. Can you please undress from the waist down and lie down on the examination table for me? I'll just check your reflexes and look for any abnormalities. REQUEST TEST: General Physical Examination

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: - Deep Tendon Reflexes: 2+ (Bilateral lower extremities) - Muscle Strength: 5/5 (Bilateral lower extremities) - Sensory Perception: Normal (Bilateral lower extremities) - Abdominal Examination: Soft, non-tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds - Neurological Examination: No focal neurological deficits noted

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you please lift your legs up and bring them towards your chest, and then release them? I'd like to assess your hip flexion and check for any muscle weakness. Also, can you tell me more about your feeding history? Were you breastfed, formula-fed, or a combination of both? And did you experience any issues with feeding, such as poor latch or frequent spit-up?

speaker: Patient
text: Lifting my legs up and bringing them towards my chest feels a bit uncomfortable, but I'll try my best. It's a bit hard to explain, but when I lift my legs up, I can hear a weird sound coming from my chest. It's not really loud, but it's like a murmur that's always there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the sound you're hearing more clearly? Is it a constant murmur, or does it change pitch or volume as you lift your legs up and down?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a constant sound, kind of a whooshing noise, but it's really hard to describe. It's like a gentle humming in my chest, and it's always there, even when I'm not lifting my legs. It's just really weird, and I don't know what it is.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this whooshing noise you're hearing? Is it constant, as you said, or does it seem to change volume or pitch when you move around or change positions? Also, I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound of the Abdomen

speaker: Measurement
text: The patient reports the whooshing noise, described as a continuous "machinery" murmur, remains constant in volume and pitch regardless of movement or positional changes. RESULTS: Ultrasound of the Abdomen: No abnormalities noted in the abdominal organs, with normal blood flow and no evidence of fluid accumulation.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your feeding history, and did you experience any issues with feeding, such as poor latch or frequent spit-up? Also, I'd like to request another test: REQUEST TEST: Echocardiogram

speaker: Measurement
text: The patient's mother reports that the child had difficulty latching and frequent spit-up during feeding in infancy. The child required multiple feeding interventions and was eventually diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The patient's feeding history has been complicated since birth, and they continue to experience feeding difficulties. Echocardiogram: Findings consistent with Patent ductus arteriosus.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the feeding interventions you underwent as a baby, and how long you've been experiencing feeding difficulties? Also, can you describe the whooshing noise you're hearing more clearly, is it louder or softer when you're feeding or burping?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been really hard to describe, but when I'm feeding, it's a bit softer, like the murmur is more muffled or covered up by my own sounds. But when I'm not feeding, it's louder, and it's really hard to ignore. Sometimes my mom will cover my mouth or nose to quiet it down, and it makes me feel a bit better.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the time your mom would cover your mouth or nose to quiet down the whooshing noise? Was it always when you were feeding, or did she also cover you when you were burping or just relaxing?

speaker: Patient
text: It was mostly when I was feeding or trying to feed, but sometimes she'd cover me when I was burping too, just to see if it would help quiet it down. It was like she thought it might be related to feeding or digestion or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the time your mom would cover your mouth or nose to quiet down the whooshing noise? Was there a particular reason she thought it might be related to feeding or digestion? And can you describe what happened when your mom would cover your mouth or nose? Did you feel any relief, or was it more of a temporary fix?

speaker: Patient
text: It was mostly when I was feeding or trying to feed, but sometimes she'd cover me when I was burping too, just to see if it would help quiet it down. When she covers my mouth or nose, it's like the whooshing noise goes away for a little bit, and I can breathe a bit easier. It's hard to explain, but it's like the sound is somehow connected to my breathing or swallowing, and when it's covered, I feel a bit more at ease.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your breathing patterns? Do you have any difficulty catching your breath or feeling winded, even when you're just sitting still? And can you describe the sensation you experience when your mom covers your mouth or nose to quiet down the whooshing noise? Is it a feeling of relief, or is it more of a temporary sensation that wears off once she removes the covering?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to catch my breath, I feel like I'm always working a bit harder to breathe, even when I'm just sitting still. It's like my body is working harder than it should be, and it makes me feel a bit tired all the time. When my mom covers my mouth or nose, it's like a big weight is lifted off my chest, and I can breathe a bit easier. It's a feeling of relief, but it's also a bit like my body is relaxing, like it's saying, "Okay, I can handle it now." When she removes the covering, it's like my body snaps back into gear, and I feel a bit more tired again.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your heart rate, do you feel like it's beating too quickly or too slowly, even when you're just sitting still?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really think about my heart rate that much, but I do feel like I'm always a bit... off. It's hard to explain, but I feel like I'm working a bit harder than I should be to catch my breath, even when I'm just sitting still. It's like my heart is beating a bit too fast, but not too fast, just... different.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of being "off" when you're sitting still? Is it a constant sensation, or does it come and go at certain times of the day or when you're in different situations? Also, I'd like to request another test: REQUEST TEST: ECG

speaker: Measurement
text: The patient describes the feeling of being "off" as a constant sensation, present throughout the day, and not necessarily linked to specific situations. It's more of a general feeling of unease or discomfort. The patient also reports episodes of feeling lightheaded and experiencing occasional syncope (fainting). REQUEST TEST: ECG

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these episodes of feeling lightheaded and experiencing syncope? How often do they happen, and under what circumstances? Also, I'd like to review the ECG results again and see if we can find any clues about what might be causing these symptoms. One more question, when you were a baby, did you ever experience any episodes of apnea, or pauses in breathing while you were sleeping?

speaker: Patient
text: I think I had a few episodes of apnea when I was a baby, but I don't really remember. My mom would always be there to help me breathe, and it would stop as soon as she was holding me or feeding me. But sometimes it would happen when I was sleeping, and it would be really scary because I would feel like I was choking or something.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the apnea episodes you had as a baby? How long would you typically stop breathing, and did you ever have any episodes that lasted for an extended period of time?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really remember the exact length of time I would stop breathing, but it felt like a really long time. And sometimes it would happen when I was sleeping, and it would be really scary because I would feel like I was choking or something. I think my mom would always be there to help me breathe, but sometimes I would wake up and feel really tired, like I had been holding my breath for a really long time.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the patient's symptoms and test results. I'd like to review the ECG results again to see if we can find any clues about what might be causing these symptoms. Can you tell me more about the ECG results? Were there any abnormal readings, such as arrhythmias or conduction delays? And did the ECG show any signs of cardiac hypertrophy or dilation? Also, I'd like to request one more test: REQUEST TEST: Chest X-Ray.

speaker: Measurement
text: The patient's ECG results show a normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of arrhythmias or conduction delays. There are no signs of cardiac hypertrophy or dilation. However, the ECG does show a slightly elevated heart rate, consistent with the patient's previously recorded heart rate of 140 bpm. The ECG tracing also shows some minor T-wave flattening, which may be related to the patient's high heart rate or underlying cardiac condition. Chest X-Ray: No significant abnormalities noted. The cardiac silhouette is within normal limits, and there are no signs of cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, or other significant pulmonary pathology. However, there is a slight blunting of the inferior cardiac contour, which may be related to the patent ductus arteriosus identified on the echocardiogram.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the blunting of the inferior cardiac contour on the chest X-ray? Is it noticeable when you look at it, and does it seem to be related to the patent ductus arteriosus or the whooshing noise you've been experiencing? Also, I'd like to summarize what I've learned from our conversation so far. You were born at term with a low birth weight, and your mother didn't receive prenatal care. You've had difficulty latching and frequent spit-up since birth, and you were diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). You've also had episodes of apnea as a baby, and you've been experiencing a constant feeling of being "off" when you're sitting still, along with episodes of lightheadedness and syncope. The echocardiogram showed findings consistent with patent ductus arteriosus, and the ECG results showed a slightly elevated heart rate and some minor T-wave flattening. Is there anything else you'd like to add or any questions you have for me?

speaker: Patient
text: I just want to say that I feel really tired all the time, even when I'm not doing anything. It's like my body is always working harder than it should be. And the whooshing noise, it's just so loud sometimes. I wish I could just get rid of it. Can you please tell me more about the patent ductus arteriosus? Is that what's causing all these problems?
